And how we ought to yield it back with trust
And not with dread, whenever He should call,
Having such precious promises, through Christ
Of gain unspeakable, beyond the grave,
The listening pupil felt her heart expand
With reverent love.
Friendship, 'tween youth and age
Is gain to both,--nor least to that which finds
The germs of knowledge and experience drop
And twine themselves around the unfrosted locks,
A fadeless coronet. In this sweet home
The lengthen'd day seem'd short for their delights,
And wintry evening brief. The historic page
Made vocal, brought large wealth to memory.
The lore of distant climes, that rose and fell
Ere our New World, like Lazarus came forth,
The napkin round her forehead, and sate down
Beside her startled sisters.
Last of all,
The large time-honor'd Bible loos'd its clasps
And shed its manna on their waiting souls;
Then rose the sacred hymn in blended tones,
By Bertha's parlor-organ made intense
In melody of praise, and fervent Prayer
Set its pure crown upon the parted day,
And kiss'd the Angel, Sleep.
Yet ere they rose
From bended knee, there was a lingering pause,
A silent orison for one whose name
But seldom pass'd their lips, though in their hearts
His image with its faults and sorrows dwelt,
Invoking pity of a pardoning God.
--Thus fled the years away, the cultured glebe
Stirr'd by the vernal plough-share, yielding charms
To Summer, pouring wealth o'er Autumn's breast,
Pausing from weary toil, when Winter comes,
Bringing its Sabbath, as the man of eld
With snow upon his temples, peaceful sits
In his arm-chair, to ruminate and rest.
*     *     *     *     *
Once, at that season when the ices shrink
Befere the vernal equinox, at morn
There was no movement in the Lady's room,
Who prized the early hours like molten gold,
And ever rose before the kingly Sun.
--On the white pillow still reposed her head,
Her cheek upon her hand. She had retired
In health, affection's words, and trustful prayers
Hallowing her lips. Now, on her brow there seem'd
Unwonted smoothness, and the smile was there
Set as a seal, with which the call she heard,
"_Come! sister-spirit!_"
She had gain'd the wish
Oft utter'd to her God, to pass away
Without the sickness and enfeebled powers
That tax the heart of love. Death that unbars
Unto the ready soul the Gate of Heaven,
Claiming no pang or groan from failing flesh,
Doth angel-service.
But alas! the shock,
The chill, the change, the anguish, where she dwelt,
And must return no more. As one amaz'd
The stricken daughter held her breath for awe,
God seem'd so near. Methought she saw the Hand
That smote her. Half herself was reft away,
Body and soul. Yet no repining word
Announc'd her agony.
The tolling bell
To hill and valley, told with solemn tongue
That death had been among them, and at door
And window listening, aged crone and child
Counted its strokes, a stroke for every year,
And predicated thence, as best they might,
Whom they had lost. Neighbor of neighbor ask'd,
Till the sad tidings were possess'd by all.
--A village funeral is a thing that warns
All from their homes. In the throng'd city's bound,
Hearses unnoticed pass, and none inquire
Who goeth to his grave. But rural life
Keepeth afresh the rills of sympathy.
True sorrow was there at these obsequies,
For all the poor were mourners. There the old
Came in the garments she had given, bow'd down
With their own sense of loss. O'er furrow'd cheeks
In care-worn channels stole the trickling tear.
The young were weepers, for their memories stored
Many a gentle word, and precept kind,
Like jewels dropp'd behind her. Mothers rais'd
Their little ones above the coffin's side
To look upon her face. Lingering they gazed
Deeming the lovely Lady sweetly slept
Among the flowers that on her pillow lay.
*     *     *     *     *
He's but a tyro in the school of grief
Who hath not from the victor-tomb return'd
Unto his rifled home. The utter weight
Of whelming desolation doth not fall
Till the last rites are paid. The cares of love
Having no longer scope, withdraw their shield,
And even the seat whereon the lost one sate,
The pen he held, the cup from which he drank,
Launch their keen darts against the festering soul.
--The lonely daughter, never since her birth
Divided from the mother, having known
No separate pleasure, or secreted thought,
With deep humility resumed her course
Of daily duty and philanthropy,
Not murmuring, but remembering His great love
Who lent so long that blessing beyond price,
And from her broken censer offering still
Incense of praise.
She deem'd it fearful loss
To lose a sorrow, be chastis'd in vain,
Not yield our joys, but have them rent away,
And make this life a battle-field with God.
The sombre shadow brooding o'er their home
Was felt by all. The heart of Leonore
Dwindled and shrank beneath it. Vigor fled,
The untastcd meal, and couch bedew'd with tears
Gave the solution to her wasted flesh,
And drooping eye-lids.
Folded in her arms,
Bertha with tender accents said, "my child,
We please not her who to the angels went,
By hopeless grief. Doubt not her watchful eye
Regards us, though unseen. How oft she taught
To make God's will our own. You, who were glad
To do her bidding then, distress her not
By disobedience now. Waste not the health
In reckless martyrdom, which Heaven hath link'd
With many duties, and with hope to dwell
If faithful found, with Her who went before
And beckoning waits us."
From dull trance of grief
By kind reproof awakened, Leonore
Strove to redeem her scholarship from blame
And be a comforter, as best she might
To her remaining patroness.
*     *     *     *     *
Within
The limits of a neighboring town, a wretch
Fell by the wayside, struck by sudden Death
That vice propels. A Man of God, who sought
Like his blest Master every form of woe
Found him, and to a shelter and a couch
Convey'd. Then bending down, with earnest words
For time grew short, he urg'd him to repent.
"Say, Lord have mercy on my soul.
Look up
Unto the Lamb of God, for He can save
Even to the uttermost."
Slight heed obtain'd
This adjuration, wild the glazing eye
Fix'd on the wall,--and ever and anon
The stiffening fingers clutch'd at things unseen,
While from those spent lungs came a shuddering sound,
"_That's he! That's he!
The old man! His grey hairs
Dabbled with blood!_"
Then in a loud, long cry,
Wrung out by torturing pain,
"I struck the blow!
I tell ye that I struck the blow, and scaped.
Conrad who bore the doom is innocent,
Save fellowship with guilt."
And so he fled;
The voice of prayer around him, but the soul
Beyond its reach. The kneeling Pastor rose
Sadly, as when the Shepherd fails to snatch
A wanderer from the Lion.
But the truth
Couch'd in that dismal cry of parting life
He treasured up, and bore to those who held
Power to investigate and to reprieve;
And authorized by them with gladness sought
The gloomy prison. Conrad there he found
In sullen syncope of sickening thought,
And cautiously in measured terms disclosed
His liberation. Wondering doubt look'd forth
From eyes that opening wide and wider still
Strain'd from their sockets. Yet the hand he took
That led him from the cell, and onward moved
Like Peter following his angel guide
Deeming he saw a vision. As the bolts
Drew gratingly to let them pass, he seem'd
To gather consciousness, and restless grew
With an unspoken fear, lest at the last
Some sterner turnkey, or gruff sentinel
Might bar their egress.
When behind them closed.
The utmost barrier, and the sweet, fresh air
So long witheld, fill'd his collapsing lungs,
He shouted rapturously,
"_Am I alive?_
Or have I burst the gates of death, and found
A second Eden?"
The unwonted sound
Of his own voice, freed from the drear constraint
Of prison durance, swell'd his thrilling frame
With strong and joyous impulse, for 'tis said
Long stifled utterance is torturing pain
To organs train'd to speech.
With one high leap
Like an enfranchis'd steed he seem'd to throw
His spirit-chain behind him. Then he took
The Pastor's offer'd arm, who led the way
To his own house, and bade him bathe and change
His prison garments, and repose that night
Under his roof.
With thoughtful care he spoke
To his own household, kindly to receive
The erring one,--"for we are sinners all,
And not upon our merits may depend
But on abounding grace."
So when the hour
Of cheerful supper summon'd to the board,
He came among them as a comely guest,
Refresh'd and welcome. Pleasant converse cheer'd
The hospitable meal, and then withdrawn
Into the quiet study 'mid the books,
That saintly good man with the hoary hair
Silvering his temples like a graceful crown,
Strove by wise counsel to encourage him
For life's important duties,
But he deem'd
A ban was on him, and a mark which all
Would scan who met him.
"He whose lot hath been
With fiends in Pandemonium, must expect
Hate and contempt from men."
"Not so, my son!
Wipe off the past, as a forgotten thing,
Propitiate virtue, by forsaking vice.
The good will aid you, and a brighter day
Doubtless awaits you. Be not too much moved
By man's applause or blame, but ever look
Unto a higher Judge."
Then there arose
A voice of supplication, so intense
To the Great Pardoner, that He would send
His spirit down to change and purify
The erring heart, that those persuasive tones,
So humble, yet so strangely eloquent
Breathed o'er the unhappy one like soothing spell
Of magic influence, and he slept that night
With peace and hope, long exiled from his couch.
*     *     *     *     *
A summer drive to one sequestered long,
Hath charms untold.
The common face of earth,
The waving grass, the rustle of the leaves,
Kiss'd by the zephyr, or by winged bird
Disparted, as it finds its chirping nest,
The murmur of the brooks, the low of herds,
The ever-changing landscape, rock and stream,
And azure concave fleck'd with silver clouds
Awaken rapturous joy. This Conrad felt,
While pleasure every kindling feature touch'd,
And every accent tuned. But when they saw
The fair ancestral roof through trees afar,
Strong agony convuls'd him, and he cried,
"_Not there! Not there!_
First take me to _Her_ grave!"
And so to that secluded spot they turn'd,
Where rest the silent dead.
On the green mound,
His Mother's bed, with sobs and groans he fell,
And in his paroxysm of grief would fain
Have torn the turf-bound earth away, to reach
The mouldering coffin. Then, a flood of tears,
Heaven's blessed gift burst forth,
"Oh weep, my Son!
These gushing tears shall help to wash away
Remorseful pangs, and lurking seeds of sin.
Here, in this sacred tomb, bury the past,
And strong in heavenly trust, resolve to rise
To a new life."
Still kneeling on the sod
With hands and eyes uprais'd, he said,
"_I will!
So help me God!_"
The tear was on his cheek
Undry'd, when to the home of peace they came.
There Bertha greeted them with outstretch'd hands
And beaming brow, while the good Pastor said,
"Thy Son was dead, but is alive again."
A sweet voice answer'd,
"Lost he was, and found!
Oh, welcome home."
She would have folded him
In her embrace. But at her feet he fell,
Clasping her knees, and bowing down his head,
Till she assured him that a mother's love
Was in her heart.
"And there is joy in Heaven
Because of him, this day," the good Man said.
--His tones were tremulous, as up he rose,
"Ah, my veil'd Angel! Now I see thy face,
And hear thy voice."
*     *     *     *     *
What were the glowing thoughts
Of the meek shepherd, as alone he took
His homeward way? The joy of others flow'd
O'er his glad spirit like a refluent tide
Whose sands were gold. Had he not chosen well
His source of happiness?
There are, who mix
Pride and ambition with their services
Before the altar. Did the tinkling bells
Upon the garments of the Jewish priest
Draw down his thoughts from God?
The mitred brow,
Doth it stoop low enough to find the souls
That struggle in the pits of sin, and die?
Methinks ambitious honors might disturb
The man whose banner is the Cross of Christ,
And earth's high places shut him out of Heaven.
--Yet this serene disciple, so content
To do his Master's will, in humblest works
Of charity, had he not chosen well
His happiness?
The hero hears the trump
Of victor-fame, and his high pulses leap,
But laurels dipp'd in blood shall vex his soul
When the death-ague comes. More blest is he
Who bearing on his brow the anointing oil
Keeps in his heart the humility and zeal
That sanctify his vows. So, full of joy
That fears no frost of earth, because its root
Is by the river of eternal life,
The white-hair'd Pastor took his homeward way.
*     *     *     *     *
New life upon the farm. A master's eye
And step are there. Forest, and cultured field,
And garden feel his influence. Forth at morn
He goes amid the laboring hinds who bathe
Their scythe in fragrant dew, mid all their toils
Teaching or learning, with such cheerful port
As won their hearts.
Even animals partook
His kind regard. The horse, with arching neck,
And ear erect, replied as best he might
To his caressing tones. The patient ox,
With branching horns, and the full-udder'd cow
Grew sleek and flourish'd and in happiest guise
Reveal'd his regency. The noble dog,
O'erflowing with intelligence and zeal,
Follow'd him as a friend; even the poor cat
Oft scorn'd and distanc'd, till her fawning love
Turns into abjectness, crept to his knee
Without reproof, and thro' her half-shut eyes
Regarding him, ere into sleep she sank
With song monotonous, express'd her joy.
--He loved to hear the clarion of the cock,
And see him in his gallantry protect
The brooding mothers,--of their infant charge
So fond and proud.
The generous care bestow'd
For weal and comfort of these servitors
And their mute dialect of gratitude
Pleas'd and refresh'd him, while those blessed toils
That quicken earth's fertility bestowed
The boon of healthful vigor. Bertha found
The burden of her cares securely laid
On his young arm, and gratefully beheld
Each day a portion of allotted time
Spent in the library, with earnest care,
Seeking the knowledge that in youth he scorn'd.
--Amid their rural neighborhood were some
Who frankly took him by the hand, as one,
Worthy to rise, and others who preferr'd
To cherish evil memories, or indulge
Dark auguries. But on his course he held
Unmov'd by either, for to her he seem'd
Intent and emulous alone to please
A higher Judge. When leaning on his arm
She sought the House of God, her tranquil brow
Seem'd in its time-tried beauty to express
The _Nunc Dimittis_.
Prisons are not oft
Converting places. Vicious habits shorn
Of their top branches, strike a rankling root
Darkly beneath, while hatred of mankind
And of the justice that decreed such doom
Bar out the Love Divine.
Yet Bertha felt
God's spirit was not limited, and might
Pluck brands from out the burning, and in faith
Believ'd the son of many prayers had found
Remission of his God. His life she scann'd,
Of honest, cheerful industry, combined
With intellectual progress, and perceived
How his religious worship humbly wore
The signet "_I have sinn'd;_" while toward men
His speech was cautious, far beyond his years,
As one by stern Experience school'd to know
The human heart's deceptions. Yet at home
And in that fellowship with Nature's works
Which Agriculture gives, his soul threw off
Its fetters and grew strong.
Once as they walk'd
Within a favorite grove, consulting where
The woodman's ax, or pruning-knife had best
Exert their wholesome ministry, he led
To a fair resting-place, a turf-bound seat,
Beneath a spreading Walnut, carpeted
With depth of fragrant leaves, while a slight brook
Half-hidden, half revealed, with minstrel touch,
Soften'd the spirit. There, in tones subdued
By strong emotion, he disclosed his love
For Leonore.
"Oh Conrad! she is pure
And peaceful as the lily bud that sleeps
On the heaven-mirror'd lake."
"I know it well,
Nor would I wake a ripple or a breath
To mar its purity."
"Yet wait, my Son!"
"_Wait? Mother, wait! It is not in man's heart
To love, and wait?_"
"But make your prayer to God.
Lay your petition at his feet, and see
What is His will."
"Before that God I swear
To be her true protector and best friend
Till death remove me hence, if she confide
At fitting time, that holy trust to me.
Oh angel Mother! sanction me to search
If in her heart there be one answering chord
To my great love. So may we lead below
That blended life which with a firmer step
And holier joy tends upward toward a realm
Of perfect bliss."
Thus authorized, he made
Her mind's improvement his delight, and found
Community in knowledge was a spell
To draw young hearts together. O'er the lore
And language of her native land they hung
Gleaning its riches with a tireless hand,
Deep and enamour'd students. When she sang
Or play'd, he join'd her with his silvery flute,
Making the thrill of music more intense
Through the heart's harmony.
Amid the flowers
He met her, and her garden's pleasant toil
Shared with a master's hand, for well he knew
The nature and the welfare of the plants
That most she prized. They loved the umbrageous trees,
And in their strong, columnar trunks beheld
The Almighty Architect, and for His sake
Paid them respect.
At the soft twilight hour,
He sate beside her silently, and watch'd
The pensive lustre of her lifted eye,
Intent to welcome the first star that hung
Its holy cresset forth. Unconsciously
Her moods of lonely musing stole away,
And his endear'd society became
Part of her being.
In her soul was nought
Of vanity, or coquetry to bar
That heaven-imparted sentiment which makes
All hope, all thought, all self, subordinate
Unto another's weal, while life shall last.
*     *     *     *     *
One morn, the orphan sought the private ear
Of her kind benefactress.
In low tones
With the sweet modesty of innocence,
She told that Conrad offered her his heart,
And in the tender confidence of trust
Entreated counsel from her changeless friend.
"Can you o'erlook the past, my Leonore?"
"Our God forgives the penitent. And we
So prone to error, cannot we forgive?
The change in Conrad, months and years have made
More evident.
Might I but sooth away
The memory of his woes, and aid his feet
More steadfastly to tread in virtue's path,
And make him happier on his way to Heaven,
My life and love I'd gladly consecrate."
*     *     *     *     *
Wrapp'd in her arms the foster-mother gave
A tearful blessing, while on bended knee
Together they implored the approving smile
Of Him, who gives ability to make
And keep the covenant of unending love.
A rural bridal,
Cupid's ancient themes
Though more than twice-told, seem not wearisome
Or obsolete. The many tomes they prompt,
Though quaint or prolix, still a place maintain
In library or boudoir, and seduce
The school-girl from her sleep, and lessons too.
But I no tint of romance have to throw
On this plain tale, or o'er the youthful pair
Who gladly took the irrevocable vow.
*     *     *     *     *
Their deep and thoughtful happiness required
No herald pomp. Buds of the snowy rose,
On brow and bosom, were the only gems
Of the young fair-hair'd bride, whose ringlets fell
Down to her shoulders:--nature's simple veil
Of wondrous grace.
A few true hearted friends
Witness'd the marriage-rite, with cheering smiles
And fervent blessings.
And the coming years
With all their tests of sunshine or of shade,
Belied no nuptial promise, striving each
With ardent emulation to surpass
Its predecessor in the heavenward path
Of duty and improvement.
Bertha's prayers
Were ever round them as a thread of gold
Wove daily in the warp and woof of life.
In their felicity she found her own
Reduplicated. In good deeds to all
Who sought her aid, or felt the sting of woe,
With unimpaired benevolence she wrought,
And tireless sympathy.
Ordain'd she seem'd
To show the beauty of the life that hath
God for its end.
Clearer its brightness gleam'd
As nearer to its heavenly goal it drew.
The smile staid with her till she went above,
Death harm'd it not. Her passport to that clime
Where Love begun on earth, doth end in joy,
Forevermore.

### 1. Summary

"The Rural Life In New-England" by Lydia Howard Sigourney is a nostalgic and detailed depiction of the agrarian lifestyle in New England. The poem emphasizes the simplicity, industriousness, and moral integrity of rural life. Sigourney contrasts these virtues with the complexities and vanities of urban existence. The poem reflects a deep appreciation for the natural world, a strong sense of community, and a reverence for the past. The key emotions conveyed include admiration, nostalgia, and a sense of loss for the fading traditional ways.

### 2. Stanza-by-Stanza Breakdown

#### Stanza 1
- **Summary:** Describes the peaceful and industrious life of rural New Englanders, who live simply and in harmony with nature.
- **Literary Devices:** Uses personification ("Walking filially with Nature as the Patriarchs walked with God"), and a simile.
- **Contribution:** Establishes the foundational theme of idealized rural life.

#### Stanza 2
- **Summary:** Discusses the unadorned and homely lifestyle of ancestral farmers and their wives, who were vigorous and courageous.
- **Literary Devices:** Uses metaphor ("seed-planters of a strong nation") and alliteration.
- **Contribution:** Reinforces the theme of strength and simplicity in rural life.

#### Stanza 3
- **Summary:** Pays homage to the ancient farmer, describing his physical strength and contentment with his lot.
- **Literary Devices:** Metaphor ("Broad-shouldered as Ajax"), and personification ("commerce with free air").
- **Contribution:** Highlights the physical and moral virtues of the rural farmer.

#### Stanza 4
- **Summary:** Describes the farmer's true independence, supported by nature and toil, and contrasts it with the luxury and care of city life.
- **Literary Devices:** Personification (earth and sky as "bankers"), and simile.
- **Contribution:** Emphasizes the farmer's self-sufficiency and the purity of rural labor.

#### Stanza 5
- **Summary:** Continues discussing the farmer's independence and his reliance on nature for sustenance.
- **Literary Devices:** Personification and imagery (e.g., "Birds, newly-returned, the merry nest-builders").
- **Contribution:** Further develops the theme of self-reliance and harmony with nature.

#### Stanza 6
- **Summary:** Explores the role of women in rural life, highlighting their contributions to the household.
- **Literary Devices:** Personification and imagery.
- **Contribution:** Acknowledges the hard work and skills of rural women.

#### Stanza 7
- **Summary:** Describes the maple tree and the process of making maple sugar, a cherished rural tradition.
- **Literary Devices:** Personification ("Tubes inserted through its bark, drew away the heart's sweet blood"), simile.
- **Contribution:** Highlights the connection between rural life and nature.

#### Stanza 8
- **Summary:** Describes the honeybee's role in rural life and the practical uses of honey and wax.
- **Literary Devices:** Personification ("Gamboling among wild flowers, gadded the honey-bee").
- **Contribution:** Showcases the resourcefulness of rural people.

#### Stanza 9
- **Summary:** Discusses the rural household's self-sufficiency and the importance of prudence and economy.
- **Literary Devices:** Imagery and metaphor.
- **Contribution:** Reinforces the theme of self-reliance and practical wisdom.

#### Stanza 10
- **Summary:** Celebrates the agricultural cycle and the contentment it brings.
- **Literary Devices:** Imagery and personification.
- **Contribution:** Highlights the satisfaction derived from agricultural labor.

#### Stanza 11
- **Summary:** Describes the cozy, harmonious family life in rural New England.
- **Literary Devices:** Imagery and alliteration.
- **Contribution:** Illustrates the warmth and unity of rural family life.

#### Stanza 12
- **Summary:** Describes the winter evenings filled with reading, learning, and family bonding.
- **Literary Devices:** Imagery and simile.
- **Contribution:** Highlights the intellectual and familial aspects of rural life.

#### Stanza 13
- **Summary:** Discusses the importance of education in rural life and the simple, yet effective, schooling system.
- **Literary Devices:** Imagery and alliteration.
- **Contribution:** Emphasizes the value placed on education and self-improvement.

#### Stanza 14
- **Summary:** Describes the communal and festive nature of Thanksgiving in rural New England.
- **Literary Devices:** Imagery and metaphor.
- **Contribution:** Highlights the importance of community and tradition.

#### Stanza 15
- **Summary:** Reflects on the contentment and acceptance of life's hardships in rural New England.
- **Literary Devices:** Metaphor and personification.
- **Contribution:** Emphasizes the philosophical and spiritual acceptance of rural life.

#### Stanza 16
- **Summary:** Describes the changes and refinements that came with the progress of time.
- **Literary Devices:** Imagery and metaphor.
- **Contribution:** Acknowledges the evolution of rural life while maintaining its core values.

#### Stanza 17
- **Summary:** Describes the daily life of a refined rural lady and her daughters.
- **Literary Devices:** Imagery and personification.
- **Contribution:** Highlights the blending of refinement and practicality in rural life.

#### Stanza 18
- **Summary:** Describes the lady's daughters, their activities, and their harmonious relationship with nature.
- **Literary Devices:** Imagery and personification.
- **Contribution:** Emphasizes the natural and joyful aspects of rural childhood.

#### Stanza 19
- **Summary:** Describes the two daughters' different temperaments and their shared joys.
- **Literary Devices:** Imagery and metaphor.
- **Contribution:** Highlights the diversity and unity within rural families.

#### Stanza 20
- **Summary:** Describes the daughters' personalities and their harmonious relationship.
- **Literary Devices:** Imagery and simile.
- **Contribution:** Emphasizes the closeness and love within rural families.

#### Stanza 21
- **Summary:** Reflects on the daughters' love for nature and their simple, yet profound, joys.
- **Literary Devices:** Imagery and personification.
- **Contribution:** Highlights the deep connection between rural life and nature.

#### Stanza 22
- **Summary:** Describes the daughters' different interests and their shared love for their mother.
- **Literary Devices:** Imagery and metaphor.
- **Contribution:** Emphasizes the importance of family and nature in rural life.

#### Stanza 23
- **Summary:** Describes the daughters' love for each other and their shared experiences.
- **Literary Devices:** Imagery and personification.
- **Contribution:** Highlights the enduring bonds of family in rural life.

#### Stanza 24
- **Summary:** Reflects on the daughters' gratitude and the importance of family bonds.
- **Literary Devices:** Metaphor and personification.
- **Contribution:** Emphasizes the values of gratitude and family in rural life.

#### Canto Second
- **Summary:** Describes Miranda's experience in a city boarding school, her vanity, and her eventual return home, where she faces family concerns about her unsuitable lover.
- **Literary Devices:** Imagery and metaphor.
- **Contribution:** Contrasts rural simplicity with urban vanity and foreshadows future conflicts.

#### Canto Third
- **Summary:** Describes Miranda's marriage, her subsequent abandonment, and her return to her family, where she finds solace. Conrad, experiencing redemption, returns home and contributes to the farm's prosperity.
- **Literary Devices:** Imagery, metaphor, and personification.
- **Contribution:** Highlights themes of redemption, forgiveness, and the enduring strength of rural values.

### 3. Structure and Form

The poem is structured into three cantos, each focusing on different aspects of rural life and the characters' experiences. The rhyme scheme varies, and the meter is predominantly iambic, giving the poem a rhythmic and contemplative tone. The use of enjambment and caesura adds to the flowing narrative style. Repetition is used effectively to emphasize key themes and emotions.

### 4. Imagery, Symbolism, and Figurative Language

- **Imagery:** The poem is rich in imagery, describing the natural landscape, agricultural activities, and rural household scenes in vivid detail.
- **Symbolism:** Rural life symbolizes simplicity, morality, and a connection to nature. The maple tree and honeybee symbolize the resourcefulness and self-sufficiency of rural people.
- **Figurative Language:** The poem uses metaphors ("seed-planters of a strong nation"), similes ("as the Patriarchs walked with God"), and personification ("commerce with free air") to enhance its meaning and emotional resonance.

### 5. Tone and Mood

- **Tone:** The tone is nostalgic, admiring, and reflective. Sigourney expresses a deep appreciation for the virtues of rural life and a sense of loss for its fading traditions.
- **Mood:** The mood is serene and contemplative, with moments of melancholy and solemnity, especially when reflecting on the changes brought by time and the challenges faced by the characters.

author: Michelangelo di Lodovico Buonarroti Simoni
title: On Dante Alighieri.
poem:
Dal ciel discese.
From heaven his spirit came, and robed in clay
The realms of justice and of mercy trod,
Then rose a living man to gaze on God,
That he might make the truth as clear as day.
For that pure star that brightened with his ray
The undeserving nest where I was born,
The whole wide world would be a prize to scorn;
None but his Maker can due guerdon pay.
I speak of Dante, whose high work remains
Unknown, unhonoured by that thankless brood,
Who only to just men deny their wage.
Were I but he! Born for like lingering pains,
Against his exile coupled with his good
I'd gladly change the world's best heritage!
interpretation:
## 1. Summary

"On Dante Alighieri" by Michelangelo expresses profound admiration for Dante, portraying him as a heavenly figure who descended to Earth to reveal divine truths. The poem highlights Dante's justice, mercy, and dedication to making truth clear. Michelangelo laments that Dante's work remains unappreciated by the world and expresses a desire to endure similar hardships to gain Dante's virtues.

## 2. Stanza-by-Stanza Breakdown

### Stanza 1
**Content:**
- The poem begins by stating that Dante's spirit descended from heaven and lived in a human body.
- Dante walked the realms of justice and mercy, and after death, he ascended to gaze upon God.
- His purpose was to make divine truth clear to humanity.

**Literary Devices:**
- **Imagery:** "robed in clay" symbolizes human form; "realms of justice and of mercy" convey Dante's moral journey.
- **Metaphor:** "pure star" represents Dante's enlightening influence.
- **Personification:** Truth is personified as something Dante makes clear.

**Contribution to Theme:**
- Establishes Dante as a divine messenger, emphasizing his heavenly origin and mission on Earth.

### Stanza 2
**Content:**
- Michelangelo regards Dante as a bright star that illuminated the unworthy place of his birth.
- He asserts that the world is unworthy of Dante and only God can reward him adequately.

**Literary Devices:**
- **Metaphor:** "pure star" continues to symbolize Dante's divine brilliance.
- **Hyperbole:** "The whole wide world would be a prize to scorn" exaggerates to emphasize Dante's unparalleled value.
- **Alliteration:** "due guerdon" for emphasis on the reward.

**Contribution to Theme:**
- Highlights the poet's reverence for Dante, suggesting that earthly rewards are insufficient for his contributions.

### Stanza 3
**Content:**
- Michelangelo laments that Dante's work is unrecognized and unhonored by the ungrateful people.
- He expresses a wish to endure Dante's exile and suffering to achieve similar greatness.

**Literary Devices:**
- **Irony:** The "thankless brood" ironically refers to those who fail to appreciate just men.
- **Allusion:** Reference to Dante's exile, aligning Michelangelo's desires with Dante's experiences.
- **Contrast:** Comparing the world's heritage with the value of Dante's virtues.

**Contribution to Theme:**
- Emphasizes the lack of recognition for true greatness and Michelangelo's deep admiration and aspiration towards Dante's virtues.

## 3. Structure and Form

The poem consists of three stanzas, each with four lines (quatrains). The rhyme scheme follows ABBA. The meter is iambic pentameter, giving the poem a rhythmic and formal quality that enhances its reverent tone. The use of enjambment allows thoughts to flow seamlessly across lines, reflecting the continuous admiration and complex feelings Michelangelo has for Dante.

## 4. Imagery, Symbolism, and Figurative Language

- **Imagery:** "robed in clay" and "pure star" create vivid images of Dante's divine nature and human form.
- **Symbolism:** The "pure star" symbolizes Dante's enlightening influence and divine wisdom.
- **Metaphors:** Referencing Dante as a star and his work as a divine mission enhances his portrayal as a celestial figure.
- **Personification:** Truth is personified, illustrating Dante's role in making divine truths accessible.

These elements deepen the reader's understanding of Dante's significance and Michelangelo's reverence for him.

## 5. Tone and Mood

- **Tone:** The tone is admiring and reverent, reflecting deep respect and devotion towards Dante.
- **Mood:** The mood is contemplative and somber, infused with a sense of longing and admiration for Dante's virtues and contributions.

Michelangelo's language and literary devices effectively convey his profound respect for Dante and his wish to emulate his greatness, creating a powerful homage to the poet.

author: Hattie Howard
title: A Reformer.
poem:
When I was young, my heart elate
With ardent notions warm,
I thirsted to inaugurate
A spirit of reform;
The universe was all awry,
Philosophy despite,
And mundane things disjointed I
Was bound to set aright.
My mind conceived a million plans,
For Hope was brave and strong,
But dared not with unaided hands
Combat a giant wrong;
So with caress I sought to coax
Those who had humored me
In infancy - the dear old folks -
And gain their sympathy.
But quarreling with extant laws
They would have deemed a shame
Who clung to error, just because
Their fathers did the same.
I sought in Pleasure's gilded halls,
Where grace and beauty stirred
At revelry's impetuous calls,
To make my projects heard.
Then turned to stately palaces
Of luxury and ease,
Where wealth's absorbing object was
The master's whim to please;
And spoke of evils unredressed,
Of danger yet to be -
They only answered, like the rest:
"But what is that to me?"
And even pious devot'es
Whom sacred walls immure
Condemned me (as by feeble praise) -
What more could I endure?
Down by the stream, so pure and clear
That sunbeams paused to drink,
In loneliness and grief sincere
I pressed its grassy brink.
Thick darkness seemed to veil the day;
Beyond a realm of tears
Utopia's land of promise lay;
And not till later years
I learned this lesson - that to win
Results from labor sure,
"Reformers" always must begin
Among the lowly poor.
For they whose lot privation is
And whose delights are few,
Whose aggregate of miseries
Is want of something new,
The measure of whose happiness
Is but an empty cup,
For every novelty will press
Alert to fill it up.

# Analysis of "A Reformer" by Hattie Howard

## 1. Summary
The poem "A Reformer" by Hattie Howard explores the journey of a young idealist eager to initiate societal reform. The poet conveys the challenges and disillusionments faced by the reformer as they attempt to garner support from various social strata. Ultimately, the poem highlights the realization that true reform must begin among the impoverished and marginalized, as they are the most receptive to change due to their dire circumstances.

## 2. Stanza-by-Stanza Breakdown

### Stanza 1
- **Summary**: The speaker, in their youth, is filled with enthusiasm and a desire to reform the flawed world.
- **Literary Devices**: Metaphor ("the universe was all awry"), personification ("mundane things disjointed").
- **Contribution to Theme**: Establishes the speaker's initial idealism and determination to correct societal wrongs.

### Stanza 2
- **Summary**: Despite having many ideas, the speaker realizes they cannot tackle large issues alone and seeks support from those close to them.
- **Literary Devices**: Personification (Hope being "brave and strong").
- **Contribution to Theme**: Highlights the speaker's initial reliance on others for support in their reform efforts.

### Stanza 3
- **Summary**: The speaker attempts to gain the sympathy of their elders, who dismiss the idea of reform due to adherence to tradition.
- **Literary Devices**: Irony (the elders' clinging to outdated beliefs).
- **Contribution to Theme**: Demonstrates the difficulty of changing established norms and the resistance from those entrenched in tradition.

### Stanza 4
- **Summary**: The speaker tries to introduce their reform ideas in places of pleasure and beauty but finds them unheeded.
- **Literary Devices**: Imagery ("Pleasure's gilded halls").
- **Contribution to Theme**: Shows the disinterest of those engaged in pleasure and luxury in societal issues.

### Stanza 5
- **Summary**: The speaker then turns to wealthy individuals, who are similarly uninterested in addressing societal evils.
- **Literary Devices**: Irony (the wealthy's indifference to societal problems).
- **Contribution to Theme**: Emphasizes the apathy of the affluent towards reform efforts.

### Stanza 6
- **Summary**: Even religious devotees, who should be morally inclined to support reform, condemn the speaker.
- **Literary Devices**: Irony (the pious condemning reform) and enjambment.
- **Contribution to Theme**: Illustrates the hypocrisy and complacency within religious circles.

### Stanza 7
- **Summary**: The speaker, feeling despondent, seeks solace by a clear stream, reflecting on their failures and the elusive nature of utopia.
- **Literary Devices**: Imagery (the clear stream, "sunbeams paused to drink"), personification (sunbeams drinking).
- **Contribution to Theme**: Conveys the speaker's emotional turmoil and sense of isolation.

### Stanza 8
- **Summary**: The speaker realizes that lasting reform must begin with the poor, who are most affected by societal ills and most eager for change.
- **Literary Devices**: Metaphor (empty cup as the measure of happiness).
- **Contribution to Theme**: Concludes with the insight that true reform must start from the grassroots, among the needy.

## 3. Structure and Form
The poem consists of eight quatrains (four-line stanzas) with an ABAB rhyme scheme. This structured form reflects the organized and methodical approach of the reformer. The consistent rhyme scheme aids in creating a rhythm that mirrors the reformer's persistent efforts, while enjambment throughout the poem emphasizes the continuous flow of their thoughts and struggles.

## 4. Imagery, Symbolism, and Figurative Language
- **Imagery**: Vivid descriptions like "Pleasure's gilded halls" and "stream, so pure and clear" create a strong visual impact, highlighting the contrast between different societal segments.
- **Symbolism**: The "empty cup" symbolizes the unfulfilled lives of the poor, eager to embrace change.
- **Figurative Language**: Metaphors and personification (e.g., "the universe was all awry") enhance the poem's emotional depth and convey the reformer's idealistic vision.

## 5. Tone and Mood
- **Tone**: The tone shifts from hopeful and enthusiastic to disillusioned and reflective, ultimately settling on a tone of enlightened resolve.
- **Mood**: The mood evokes a journey of idealism, frustration, and eventual clarity, leading the reader through the reformer's emotional highs and lows, and concluding with a sense of purposeful determination.

This structured analysis provides a comprehensive understanding of Hattie Howard's "A Reformer," highlighting its thematic depth, literary craftsmanship, and emotional resonance.

author: Emily Elizabeth Dickinson
title: The Wife.
poem:
She rose to his requirement, dropped
The playthings of her life
To take the honorable work
Of woman and of wife.
If aught she missed in her new day
Of amplitude, or awe,
Or first prospective, or the gold
In using wore away,
It lay unmentioned, as the sea
Develops pearl and weed,
But only to himself is known
The fathoms they abide.

# Analysis of "The Wife" by Emily Elizabeth Dickinson

## 1. Summary
"The Wife" by Emily Dickinson explores the transformation and sacrifices a woman undergoes when she becomes a wife. The poem reflects on the societal expectations placed upon women and the internal struggles they might face. It highlights themes of duty, loss of personal freedom, and unspoken sacrifices. The emotions conveyed are a mix of resignation, duty, and the nuanced acceptance of a woman's traditional role.

## 2. Stanza-by-Stanza Breakdown

### First Stanza:
**Content Summary:**
The speaker describes how a woman rises to meet her husband's expectations by leaving behind her previous life, symbolized by "playthings," and taking on the responsibilities and duties of a wife.

**Literary Devices:**
- **Metaphor:** "Dropped the playthings of her life" symbolizes leaving behind her carefree, individualistic pursuits.
- **Irony:** The phrase "honorable work" subtly critiques the traditional notion that a woman's highest honor is found only in her role as a wife.

**Contribution to Overall Theme:**
This stanza sets up the theme of sacrifice and transition, illustrating the societal expectations of a woman's role in marriage.

### Second Stanza:
**Content Summary:**
The woman might miss the freedom, ambitions, and initial excitement of her new role, but any dissatisfaction remains unspoken.

**Literary Devices:**
- **Metaphor:** "Amplitude," "awe," "first prospective," and "the gold" symbolize various aspects of personal freedom, ambition, and initial excitement.
- **Imagery:** "The gold in using wore away" creates a vivid picture of how initial excitement can diminish over time.

**Contribution to Overall Theme:**
This stanza deepens the exploration of internal conflict and the unspoken sacrifices that come with fulfilling societal roles.

### Third Stanza:
**Content Summary:**
The woman's unspoken feelings and sacrifices remain hidden, much like the mysteries of the sea, which holds both treasures and weeds beneath its surface, known only to itself.

**Literary Devices:**
- **Simile:** Comparing unspoken feelings to the sea's hidden depths.
- **Imagery:** "The sea develops pearl and weed" evokes the idea of hidden complexities and unacknowledged aspects of a woman's life.

**Contribution to Overall Theme:**
This stanza emphasizes the hidden nature of a woman's sacrifices and the complexity of her internal world, known only to herself.

## 3. Structure and Form
The poem consists of three quatrains (four-line stanzas) with an ABCB rhyme scheme, creating a subtle musicality. The relatively simple structure mirrors the conventional and straightforward expectations of a wife's role. The use of enjambment (continuation of a sentence without a pause beyond the end of a line) helps convey the ongoing, unbroken nature of the woman's inner life and duties.

## 4. Imagery, Symbolism, and Figurative Language
- **Imagery:** The "playthings of her life," "gold in using wore away," and "the sea develops pearl and weed" create vivid pictures that underscore the themes of sacrifice and hidden complexity.
- **Symbolism:** "Playthings" symbolize a woman’s personal joys and freedoms; "the sea" symbolizes the depth and hidden nature of her true feelings and sacrifices.
- **Metaphor:** The transformation from playthings to honorable work encapsulates the shift from personal freedom to societal duty.

## 5. Tone and Mood
- **Tone:** The tone is reflective and slightly melancholic, with a hint of critique toward societal expectations.
- **Mood:** The mood is contemplative and somber, evoking empathy for the woman's unspoken sacrifices and internal struggles.

This structured analysis highlights how Dickinson uses poetic devices to convey the complex emotions and societal commentary within "The Wife."

author: Vachel Lindsay
title: The Beggar Speaks
poem:
"What Mister Moon Said to Me."
Come, eat the bread of idleness,
Come, sit beside the spring:
Some of the flowers will keep awake,
Some of the birds will sing.
Come, eat the bread no man has sought
For half a hundred years:
Men hurry so they have no griefs,
Nor even idle tears:
They hurry so they have no loves:
They cannot curse nor laugh -
Their hearts die in their youth with neither
Grave nor epitaph.
My bread would make them careless,
And never quite on time -
Their eyelids would be heavy,
Their fancies full of rhyme:
Each soul a mystic rose-tree,
Or a curious incense tree:
.        .        .        .
Come, eat the bread of idleness,
Said Mister Moon to me.
interpretation:
## 1. Summary
"The Beggar Speaks" by Vachel Lindsay explores themes of idleness, the hurried nature of modern life, and the loss of emotional depth. The poem conveys a message that in the rush to be productive, people lose touch with their emotions, creativity, and the simple pleasures of life. The poet uses the figure of Mr. Moon to personify the call to embrace a more leisurely and contemplative existence.

## 2. Stanza-by-Stanza Breakdown

### Stanza 1
- **Content**: The speaker, Mr. Moon, invites the listener to enjoy idleness by sitting beside a spring where some flowers remain awake and some birds sing.
- **Literary Devices**: Personification (Mr. Moon as a speaker), Imagery (flowers awake, birds singing).
- **Contribution to Theme**: This stanza sets the peaceful and inviting tone, suggesting a life of leisure and contemplation.

### Stanza 2
- **Content**: Mr. Moon talks about a bread of idleness that has been untouched for fifty years because men are too busy to experience grief, tears, love, or other deep emotions.
- **Literary Devices**: Metaphor (bread of idleness), Hyperbole (half a hundred years).
- **Contribution to Theme**: Highlights the neglect of a slower, more emotional way of living in favor of constant busyness.

### Stanza 3
- **Content**: The stanza continues to describe how men’s hearts die young without love, laughter, or even the capacity to curse, with no memorials.
- **Literary Devices**: Metaphor (hearts die), Symbolism (grave nor epitaph).
- **Contribution to Theme**: Emphasizes the emotional and spiritual death that comes with a life of constant hurry.

### Stanza 4
- **Content**: The bread of idleness would make people carefree, dreamy, and full of poetic thoughts, with each soul becoming a mystical or curious tree.
- **Literary Devices**: Imagery (mystic rose-tree, curious incense tree), Personification.
- **Contribution to Theme**: Presents the positive transformation that idleness could bring, allowing creativity and deeper thoughts to flourish.

### Stanza 5
- **Content**: The poem closes with Mr. Moon's invitation to eat the bread of idleness.
- **Literary Devices**: Repetition ("Come, eat the bread of idleness").
- **Contribution to Theme**: Reinforces the central message of embracing leisure and contemplation.

## 3. Structure and Form
The poem consists of five stanzas with varying line lengths and a loose rhyme scheme. The irregular structure mirrors the theme of breaking away from rigid, hurried lifestyles. The use of repetition in the first and last lines bookends the poem, emphasizing the poet’s invitation to idleness.

## 4. Imagery, Symbolism, and Figurative Language
- **Imagery**: Vivid descriptions of flowers, birds, and mystical trees create a serene and inviting atmosphere.
- **Symbolism**: The "bread of idleness" symbolizes leisure and contemplation. Flowers and birds symbolize natural beauty and simplicity.
- **Figurative Language**: Metaphors like "bread of idleness" and "hearts die in their youth" convey deeper meanings about life and emotional death due to constant busyness.

## 5. Tone and Mood
- **Tone**: The tone is inviting and contemplative, with a hint of melancholy over the loss of a more leisurely way of life.
- **Mood**: The mood created for the reader is peaceful and reflective, encouraging a pause to consider the value of idleness and emotional richness.

The poem uses the calm and gentle voice of Mr. Moon to draw readers into a world where they can slow down and reconnect with their inner selves, allowing for a deeper appreciation of life's simple joys.

author: Hanford Lennox Gordon
title: Fame
poem:
Dust of the desert are thy walls
And temple-towers, O Babylon!
O'er crumbled halls the lizard crawls,
And serpents bask in blaze of sun.
In vain kings piled the Pyramids;
Their tombs were robbed by ruthless hands.
Who now shall sing their fame and deeds,
Or sift their ashes from the sands?
Deep in the drift of ages hoar
Lie nations lost and kings forgot;
Above their graves the oceans roar,
Or desert sands drift o'er the spot.
A thousand years are but a day
When reckoned on the wrinkled earth;
And who among the wise shall say
What cycle saw the primal birth
Of man, who lords on sea and land,
And builds his monuments to-day,
Like Syrian on the desert sand,
To crumble and be blown away.
Proud chiefs of pageant armies led
To fame and death their followers forth,
Ere Helen sinned and Hector bled,
Or Odin ruled the rugged North.
And poets sang immortal praise
To mortal heroes ere the fire
Of Homer blazed in Ilion lays,
Or Brage tuned the Northern lyre.
For fame men piled the Pyramids;
Their names have perished with their bones:
For fame men wrote their boasted deeds
On Babel bricks and Runic stones
On Tyrian temples, gates of brass,
On Roman arch and Damask blades,
And perished like the desert grass
That springs to-day to-morrow fades.
And still for fame men delve and die
In Afric heat and Arctic cold;
For fame on flood and field they vie,
Or gather in the shining gold.
Time, like the ocean, onward rolls
Relentless, burying men and deeds;
The brightest names, the bravest souls,
Float but an hour like ocean weeds,
Then sink forever. In the slime
Forgotten, lost forevermore,
Lies Fame from every age and clime;
Yet thousands clamor on the shore.
Immortal Fame! O dust and death!
The centuries as they pass proclaim
That Fame is but a mortal breath,
That man must perish name and fame.
The earth is but a grain of sand
An atom in a shoreless sea;
A million worlds lie in God's hand
Yea, myriad millions what are we?
O mortal man of bone and blood!
Then is there nothing left but dust?
God made us; He is wise and good,
And we may humbly hope and trust.
interpretation:
## 1. Summary

The poem "Fame" by Hanford Lennox Gordon delves into the fleeting nature of human glory and achievements. It reflects on the impermanence of fame, as historical monuments and deeds are eroded by time. Despite humanity's relentless quest for lasting recognition, the poet suggests that all human efforts are ultimately ephemeral. The poem evokes a sense of humility, questioning the significance of human endeavors in the grand scheme of the universe, and concludes with a glimmer of hope in divine wisdom and goodness.

## 2. Stanza-by-Stanza Breakdown

### Stanza 1
- **Summary**: Babylon's grandeur has turned to dust, with its structures overtaken by nature. Even the Pyramids, built by kings, have failed to preserve their fame.
- **Literary Devices**: Imagery ("serpents bask in blaze of sun"), metaphor (walls and towers as "dust of the desert"), and alliteration ("crumbled halls").
- **Contribution to Theme**: This stanza sets the stage for the poem’s theme of the futility of human endeavors against the passage of time.

### Stanza 2
- **Summary**: Many nations and kings are forgotten, buried under the ocean or desert sands.
- **Literary Devices**: Personification (oceans roaring), imagery ("drift of ages hoar").
- **Contribution to Theme**: Emphasizes the idea that no amount of human achievement can withstand the ravages of time.

### Stanza 3
- **Summary**: Time is vast, and human history is but a fleeting moment. The origins of man are lost in time.
- **Literary Devices**: Simile ("A thousand years are but a day"), metaphor (time as "wrinkled earth").
- **Contribution to Theme**: Reinforces the insignificance of human time scales compared to geological or cosmic time.

### Stanza 4
- **Summary**: Historical figures and armies sought fame long before known civilizations, yet they too are forgotten.
- **Literary Devices**: Allusion (Helen, Hector, Odin), imagery.
- **Contribution to Theme**: Suggests that the pursuit of fame is ancient and universal, yet always doomed to be forgotten.

### Stanza 5
- **Summary**: Poets once celebrated heroes, but even those songs are forgotten.
- **Literary Devices**: Allusion (Homer, Ilion, Brage), metaphor (blazed, tuned).
- **Contribution to Theme**: Highlights the transience of artistic attempts to immortalize human deeds.

### Stanza 6
- **Summary**: Men built structures and inscribed their deeds for fame, but like desert grass, they too faded away.
- **Literary Devices**: Simile ("like the desert grass"), imagery.
- **Contribution to Theme**: Continues the motif of the ephemeral nature of human achievements.

### Stanza 7
- **Summary**: The quest for fame drives men to extremes, but time eventually buries all.
- **Literary Devices**: Personification (Time as relentless), imagery (Afric heat, Arctic cold).
- **Contribution to Theme**: Illustrates the relentless pursuit of fame despite its inevitable futility.

### Stanza 8
- **Summary**: Even the brightest names are like ocean weeds, briefly floating before sinking into oblivion.
- **Literary Devices**: Simile ("like ocean weeds"), metaphor (time as ocean).
- **Contribution to Theme**: Reinforces the temporary nature of fame.

### Stanza 9
- **Summary**: Despite the transient nature of fame, people continue to seek it.
- **Literary Devices**: Irony (clamor on the shore), metaphor (time as an ocean).
- **Contribution to Theme**: Highlights the irony of humans’ persistent quest for something so fleeting.

### Stanza 10
- **Summary**: Fame is mortal and fleeting; human beings and their names are destined to perish.
- **Literary Devices**: Personification (centuries pass), metaphor (Fame as mortal breath).
- **Contribution to Theme**: Concludes the argument about the impermanence of fame.

### Stanza 11
- **Summary**: The earth is insignificant in the vast universe, and humanity's quest for fame even more so.
- **Literary Devices**: Metaphor (earth as a grain of sand), imagery.
- **Contribution to Theme**: Expands the idea of human insignificance on a cosmic scale.

### Stanza 12
- **Summary**: Despite the seeming futility of human existence, there is hope in divine wisdom and goodness.
- **Literary Devices**: Rhetorical question, personification (God as wise and good).
- **Contribution to Theme**: Ends on a note of hope, suggesting faith in a higher power despite human impermanence.

## 3. Structure and Form

The poem is structured in 12 stanzas, each comprising four lines (quatrains). The rhyme scheme varies but generally follows an ABAB pattern. The meter is predominantly iambic, contributing to a steady, reflective rhythm. The form, with its regular structure and contemplative rhythm, underscores the poem’s meditation on the cyclical and predictable nature of human endeavors and their inevitable decline.

## 4. Imagery, Symbolism, and Figurative Language

- **Imagery**: Vivid descriptions of nature reclaiming human structures (lizards, serpents, desert sands, ocean roar).
- **Symbols**: Babylon, Pyramids, and other historical references symbolize human achievements.
- **Figurative Language**: Similes ("like ocean weeds"), metaphors (time as ocean, earth as grain of sand), and personification (time as relentless, oceans roaring).

These elements enhance the poem’s theme by illustrating the transient beauty and ultimate futility of human efforts against the inexorable march of time.

## 5. Tone and Mood

- **Tone**: Reflective and melancholic, with a touch of irony.
- **Mood**: Creates a somber and contemplative atmosphere, leading to a final sense of humility and faint hope.

The poem's tone and mood guide the reader through a meditation on the ephemeral nature of fame and human existence, culminating in a resigned yet hopeful conclusion.

author: Banjo Paterson (Andrew Barton)
title: The Scottish Engineer
poem:
With eyes that searched in the dark,
Peering along the line,
Stood the grim Scotsman, Hector Clark,
Driver of "Forty-nine".
And the veldt-fire flamed on the hills ahead,
Like a blood-red beacon sign.
There was word of a fight to the north,
And a column too hardly pressed,
So they started the Highlanders forth.
Heedless of food or rest.
But the pipers gaily played,
Chanting their fierce delight,
And the armoured carriages rocked and swayed.
Laden with men of the Scots Brigade,
Hurrying up to the fight,
And the grim, grey Highland engineer
Driving them into the night.
Then a signal light glowed red,
And a picket came to the track.
"Enemy holding the line ahead;
Three of our mates we have left for dead,
Only we two got back."
And far to the north through the still night air
They heard the rifles crack.
And the boom of a gun rang out,
Like the sound of a deep appeal,
And the picket stood in doubt
By the side of the driving-wheel.
But the engineer looked down,
With his hand on the starting-bar,
"Ride ye back to the town,
Ye know what my orders are,
Maybe they're wanting the Scots Brigade
Up on those hills afar.
"I am no soldier at all,
Only an engineer;
But I could not bear that the folk should say
Over in Scotland, Glasgow way,
That Hector Clark stayed here
With the Scots Brigade till the foe was gone,
With ever a rail to run her on.
Ready behind! Stand clear!
"Fireman, get you gone
Into the armoured train,
I will drive her alone;
One more trip, and perhaps the last,
With a well-raked fire and an open blast;
Hark to the rifles again!"
*             *             *             *             *
On through the choking dark,
Never a lamp nor a light,
Never an engine spark
Showing her hurried flight,
Over the lonely plain
Rushed the great armoured train,
Hurrying up to the fight.
Then with her living freight
On to the foe she came,
And the rides snapped their hate.
And the darkness spouted flame.
Over the roar of the fray
The hungry bullets whined,
As she dashed through the foe that lay
Loading and firing blind,
Till the glare of the furnace, burning clear,
Showed them the form of the engineer
Sharply and well defined.
Through! They are safely through!
Hark to the column's cheer!
Surely the driver knew
He was to halt her here;
But he took no heed of the signals red,
And the fireman found, when he climbed ahead,
There on the door of his engine, dead,
The Scottish Engineer!
interpretation:
### 1. Summary

"The Scottish Engineer" by Banjo Paterson is a narrative poem that tells the heroic story of Hector Clark, a Scottish train engineer. Amidst a battle, Clark courageously drives an armored train through enemy lines to deliver reinforcements, ultimately sacrificing his life. The poem highlights themes of duty, bravery, and the stoic resolve of a common man in extraordinary circumstances.

### 2. Stanza-by-Stanza Breakdown

#### Stanza 1

**Summary:** Introduces Hector Clark, the grim Scottish engineer, as he peers into the darkness while driving the train "Forty-nine" with a veldt-fire blazing ahead.

**Literary Devices:** The veldt-fire is described as a "blood-red beacon sign," employing a metaphor to symbolize danger and conflict.

**Contribution to Overall Theme:** Establishes the setting and the looming peril, highlighting Clark’s vigilance and the war-torn environment.

#### Stanza 2

**Summary:** Describes the urgent dispatch of the Highlanders, who, despite their exhaustion, are spiritedly led by pipers and transported by Clark.

**Literary Devices:** The phrases "pipers gaily played" and "chanting their fierce delight" use personification to convey the soldiers' morale.

**Contribution to Overall Theme:** Shows the determination and morale of the soldiers, emphasizing the urgency and chaos of war.

#### Stanza 3

**Summary:** A signal light and a picket inform Clark that the enemy holds the line ahead, and only two men have returned from a skirmish.

**Literary Devices:** The boom of a gun is described as "the sound of a deep appeal," a metaphor indicating the gravity of the situation.

**Contribution to Overall Theme:** Introduces a critical decision point, heightening the tension and underscoring the danger.

#### Stanza 4

**Summary:** Clark, despite not being a soldier, decides to proceed, driven by a sense of duty and pride in his Scottish heritage.

**Literary Devices:** The internal monologue and dialogue reveal Clark's motivation and resolve.

**Contribution to Overall Theme:** Highlights Clark’s personal bravery and sense of duty, reinforcing the theme of sacrifice.

#### Stanza 5

**Summary:** Clark sends the fireman away and prepares to drive the train alone through the danger.

**Literary Devices:** The command to the fireman and the phrase "one more trip, and perhaps the last" use foreshadowing.

**Contribution to Overall Theme:** Emphasizes Clark’s solitary bravery and the imminent danger he faces.

#### Stanza 6

**Summary:** Describes the train's perilous journey through the dark, with no lights or sparks to guide it.

**Literary Devices:** The "choking dark" and "lonely plain" use imagery to create a sense of isolation and danger.

**Contribution to Overall Theme:** Conveys the peril and isolation faced by Clark, enhancing the tension.

#### Stanza 7

**Summary:** The train reaches the enemy, and the battle's chaos is depicted with bullets and flames.

**Literary Devices:** "Rides snapped their hate" is a metaphor for bullets, and "darkness spouted flame" uses personification.

**Contribution to Overall Theme:** Illustrates the chaos of battle and the train's relentless progress, underscoring the danger.

#### Stanza 8

**Summary:** The train successfully passes through, but Clark is found dead on the engine door.

**Literary Devices:** The cheer of the column contrasts with the discovery of Clark’s death, using irony.

**Contribution to Overall Theme:** Concludes with Clark’s ultimate sacrifice, reinforcing themes of duty and heroism.

### 3. Structure and Form

- **Stanzas:** The poem consists of eight stanzas of varying lengths.
- **Rhyme Scheme:** The rhyme scheme is irregular, contributing to the narrative flow and the unpredictability of the events.
- **Meter:** The meter is also varied, which adds to the dynamic and urgent feel of the poem.
- **Literary Devices:** Repetition and enjambment are used to maintain the poem’s pace and tension.

### 4. Imagery, Symbolism, and Figurative Language

- **Imagery:** Vivid descriptions of the veldt-fire, darkness, and battlefield create a vivid picture of the perilous journey.
- **Symbolism:** The veldt-fire symbolizes danger, and the armored train represents determination and resilience.
- **Figurative Language:** Metaphors ("blood-red beacon sign") and personification ("darkness spouted flame") enhance the emotional impact and convey the intensity of the situation.

### 5. Tone and Mood

- **Tone:** The tone is solemn and respectful, reflecting the gravity of Clark’s mission and his stoic bravery.
- **Mood:** The mood is tense and suspenseful, with a poignant sense of admiration for Clark’s sacrifice.

The poem's narrative structure, vivid imagery, and the juxtaposition of the engineer's mundane role against the backdrop of war create a powerful tribute to an unsung hero.

author: Eliza Paul Kirkbride Gurney
title: To A Friend.
poem:
Ah! be not sad, though adverse winds may blow,
Thy patience and thy fortitude to prove;
Thy Saviour wears no frown upon his brow,
"'Tis but the graver countenance of love."
Though clouds and darkness round about him roll,
In righteousness and truth He sits enthroned;
And precious in His sight the immortal soul,
For whose deep stain of guilt His love atoned.
He makes our dearest earthly comforts flee,
Or, e'en when clustering round us, bids them pall,
That thus the "altogether lovely," He,
"Chief of ten thousand," may be all in all.
And hast thou not some blissful moments known,
Even while bowed beneath the chast'ning rod,
When to thy humble spirit it was shown
That glorious is the "City of thy God?"
Hast thou not seen the King in beauty there,
And has He not assured thy fainting heart,
That from His reconciled, His child and heir,
The covenant of His peace would ne'er depart?
Has He not fully satisfied thy soul
With the pure river of His joy and love,
Subdued each murmuring thought to his control,
And stayed thy mind on changeless things above?
When He, thou callest "Abba, Father," placed
The earnest of adoption in thine heart,
Thou wast engraven, ne'er to be effaced,[A]
Upon His holy hands, and His thou art.
Then doubt no more, for the omniscient God,
All whose mysterious ways are just and true,
In life will comfort with his staff and rod,
Be near in death, and guide thee safely through.
And when the race is run, the victory given,
How sweet with the redeemed to bear the palm,
Ten thousand times ten thousand saints in Heaven,
Who hymn eternal praises to the Lamb!
interpretation:
### 1. Summary
The poem "To A Friend" by Eliza Paul Kirkbride Gurney addresses themes of faith, divine love, and spiritual comfort amid life's trials. The poet reassures the friend that adverse circumstances are a test of patience and fortitude, emphasizing God's unwavering love and righteousness. The poem conveys a message of hope, urging the friend to trust in divine guidance and find solace in the promise of eternal peace and joy.

### 2. Stanza-by-Stanza Breakdown

#### Stanza 1
- **Summary**: The poet tells the friend not to be sad despite facing difficulties, as these are tests of patience and strength. God's demeanor reflects a serious but loving nature.
- **Literary Devices**: The frown of the Saviour is a metaphor for life's challenges, and "the graver countenance of love" is a personification showing that serious circumstances are still underpinned by divine love.
- **Contribution to Theme**: This stanza introduces the idea that hardships are part of a divine plan to strengthen one's faith.

#### Stanza 2
- **Summary**: God is depicted as enthroned in righteousness and truth, valuing the immortal soul for which His love has atoned.
- **Literary Devices**: "Clouds and darkness" symbolize life's troubles, while "His love atoned" refers to the sacrifice of Jesus, emphasizing redemption.
- **Contribution to Theme**: Reinforces the concept of divine justice and the preciousness of the soul, which is central to the poem’s message of divine comfort and salvation.

#### Stanza 3
- **Summary**: Earthly comforts may flee or lose their appeal so that one may fully appreciate God's supreme love.
- **Literary Devices**: Earthly comforts are metaphorically depicted as fleeting or pallid compared to the "altogether lovely" divine love.
- **Contribution to Theme**: Highlights the transient nature of worldly pleasures and the enduring value of spiritual love.

#### Stanza 4
- **Summary**: The poet asks if the friend has experienced joy even during difficult times, recognizing the glory of God's kingdom.
- **Literary Devices**: The "chast'ning rod" symbolizes life's hardships, while "the City of thy God" is a metaphor for divine presence and eternal life.
- **Contribution to Theme**: Encourages the friend to reflect on past moments of spiritual revelation and comfort during trials.

#### Stanza 5
- **Summary**: The friend is reminded of seeing divine beauty and receiving reassurance of God's eternal peace.
- **Literary Devices**: "King in beauty" and "covenant of His peace" use imagery and metaphor to depict divine assurance and eternal promise.
- **Contribution to Theme**: Strengthens the message of divine reassurance and the eternal covenant with God.

#### Stanza 6
- **Summary**: The friend is reminded of experiencing God's joy and love, which subdues all doubts and focuses the mind on eternal truths.
- **Literary Devices**: "Pure river of His joy" and "changeless things above" are metaphors for divine blessings and eternal truths.
- **Contribution to Theme**: Emphasizes the soul's satisfaction and peace found in divine love and eternal focus.

#### Stanza 7
- **Summary**: The poet speaks of the assurance given to the friend through divine adoption, marking them as God's own forever.
- **Literary Devices**: "Engraven... upon His holy hands" is a metaphor for the indelible mark of divine belonging.
- **Contribution to Theme**: Reiterates the permanence of divine adoption and the unbreakable bond with God.

#### Stanza 8
- **Summary**: The poet urges the friend to trust in God's just and true ways, promising comfort in life and guidance through death.
- **Literary Devices**: "Staff and rod" symbolize divine guidance and support, while "guide thee safely through" is a metaphor for leading through life's end.
- **Contribution to Theme**: Assures the friend of God's constant presence and guidance, providing comfort for both life and death.

#### Stanza 9
- **Summary**: The poem concludes with a vision of heavenly victory, where the redeemed, including the friend, will celebrate eternally.
- **Literary Devices**: "Ten thousand times ten thousand saints" and "hymn eternal praises" use hyperbole and imagery to depict the grandeur of heavenly worship.
- **Contribution to Theme**: Conveys the ultimate hope and joy of eternal life in heaven, completing the poem’s arc of divine reassurance.

### 3. Structure and Form
The poem consists of 9 quatrains (four-line stanzas) with a consistent ABAB rhyme scheme. The regular meter and rhyme create a soothing, rhythmic effect, reinforcing the poem's comforting message. The use of enjambment allows thoughts to flow seamlessly between lines, reflecting the continuous and enduring nature of divine love and support.

### 4. Imagery, Symbolism, and Figurative Language
- **Imagery**: Vivid images like "clouds and darkness," "graver countenance," and "City of thy God" create a contrast between earthly struggles and divine beauty.
- **Symbolism**: The "chast'ning rod" symbolizes life's challenges, while "pure river of His joy" symbolizes divine blessings.
- **Figurative Language**: Metaphors such as "engraven... upon His holy hands" and "staff and rod" enrich the text, highlighting themes of belonging and guidance.

### 5. Tone and Mood
- **Tone**: The tone is reassuring and compassionate, reflecting the poet's intent to comfort and uplift the friend.
- **Mood**: The mood is hopeful and serene, encouraging the reader to trust in divine love and find peace amid adversity.

author: Madison Julius Cawein
title: Helen.
poem:
Heaped in raven loops and masses
Over temples smooth and fair,
Have you marked it, as she passes,
Gleam and shadow mingled there,
Braided strands of midnight air,
Helen's hair?
Deep with dreams and starry mazes
Of the thought that in them lies,
Have you seen them, as she raises
Them in gladness or surprise,
Two gray gleams of daybreak skies,
Helen's eyes?
Moist with dew and honied wafters
Of a music sweet that slips,
Have you marked them, brimmed with laughter's
Song and sunshine to their tips,
Rose-buds whence the fragrance drips,
Helen's lips?
He who sees her needs must love her:
But, beware! avoid love's dart!
He who loves her must discover
Nature overlooked one part,
In this masterpiece of art
Helen's heart.
interpretation:
## 1. Summary

The poem "Helen" by Madison Julius Cawein is a lyrical exploration of the beauty and allure of a woman named Helen. The poem's central theme revolves around the captivating physical attributes of Helen, such as her hair, eyes, and lips, which are described in a highly idealized and almost mythical manner. However, there is a twist in the concluding lines, where the poet warns that despite Helen's external perfection, there is something lacking in her—specifically, her heart. This suggests a deeper commentary on the nature of superficial beauty and the potential hollowness beneath it.

## 2. Stanza-by-Stanza Breakdown

### Stanza 1

**Summary**: The first stanza describes Helen's hair, emphasizing its beauty through its color and texture.

**Literary Devices**:
- **Metaphor**: "Heaped in raven loops and masses" compares her hair to dark, raven-like loops.
- **Imagery**: "Gleam and shadow mingled there" creates a vivid image of her hair's interplay of light and darkness.

**Contribution to Theme**: This stanza sets the tone for the poem by beginning with an idealized description of Helen's physical beauty. It establishes the theme of external allure.

### Stanza 2

**Summary**: The second stanza focuses on Helen's eyes, highlighting their depth and the dreams they contain.

**Literary Devices**:
- **Metaphor**: "Two gray gleams of daybreak skies" compares her eyes to the morning sky.
- **Imagery**: "Deep with dreams and starry mazes" paints a picture of the mysterious and enchanting nature of her eyes.

**Contribution to Theme**: This stanza deepens the theme of Helen's mesmerizing beauty, suggesting that her eyes hold a world of dreams and wonder.

### Stanza 3

**Summary**: The third stanza describes Helen's lips, noting their sweetness and the joy they convey.

**Literary Devices**:
- **Imagery**: "Moist with dew and honied wafters" creates a sensory image of her lips.
- **Metaphor**: "Rose-buds whence the fragrance drips" compares her lips to fragrant rosebuds.

**Contribution to Theme**: This stanza continues the idealization of Helen's physical features, emphasizing the sensory pleasure they provide.

### Stanza 4

**Summary**: The final stanza shifts to a cautionary note, suggesting that while Helen's beauty is captivating, her heart is missing or incomplete.

**Literary Devices**:
- **Irony**: The warning to "avoid love's dart" contrasts with the previous stanzas' adoration of Helen's beauty.
- **Metaphor**: "Masterpiece of art" refers to Helen as a creation of nature, but with a significant flaw.

**Contribution to Theme**: This stanza introduces a critical perspective, suggesting that Helen's external beauty conceals an inner deficiency, thus complicating the poem's overall portrayal of beauty.

## 3. Structure and Form

The poem consists of four stanzas, each with six lines (sestets). The rhyme scheme is AABBBB, which creates a sense of continuity and flow. The meter is predominantly iambic, which lends a rhythmic and lyrical quality to the poem. The use of enjambment in some lines enhances the fluidity of the description. The structured form contributes to the poem's harmonious and balanced depiction of Helen's beauty, while the consistent rhyme scheme and meter reflect the poet's admiration.

## 4. Imagery, Symbolism, and Figurative Language

- **Imagery**: The poem is rich with visual and sensory imagery, such as "raven loops," "daybreak skies," and "moist with dew." These images vividly portray Helen's physical features.
- **Symbolism**: Helen's beauty symbolizes an idealized form of femininity and allure.
- **Metaphors**: Comparisons like "raven loops" for hair and "rose-buds" for lips enhance the poem's descriptive quality, elevating Helen's beauty to a near-mythical level.
- **Personification**: The poem attributes human-like qualities to Helen's features, such as her eyes being "deep with dreams."

These elements collectively enhance the poem's exploration of beauty by creating a vivid, almost otherworldly image of Helen.

## 5. Tone and Mood

- **Tone**: The tone of the poem is initially admiring and reverent, reflecting the poet's awe at Helen's beauty. However, it shifts to a more cautionary and critical tone in the final stanza.
- **Mood**: The mood is one of fascination and enchantment, evoking a sense of wonder in the reader. The concluding lines introduce a subtle sense of disappointment or disillusionment.

The tone and mood work together to create a complex portrayal of Helen, celebrating her beauty while also hinting at its superficiality.

author: Robert Herrick
title: Upon One Lily, Who Married With A Maid Called Rose.
poem:
What times of sweetness this fair day foreshows,
Whenas the Lily marries with the Rose!
What next is look'd for? but we all should see
To spring from thee a sweet posterity.
interpretation:
## Analysis of "Upon One Lily, Who Married With A Maid Called Rose" by Robert Herrick

### 1. Summary
The poem "Upon One Lily, Who Married With A Maid Called Rose" by Robert Herrick celebrates the union of two individuals, symbolized by the lily and rose. The poet anticipates that this marriage will bring sweetness and beauty, and he looks forward to the prospect of a harmonious and beautiful lineage arising from this union. The themes revolve around love, union, and the hope for a beautiful future.

### 2. Stanza-by-Stanza Breakdown

#### Lines 1-2
**Summary:** The poet remarks on the sweetness and beauty that the day promises as the lily marries the rose.
**Literary Devices:**
- **Metaphor:** The marriage of the lily and the rose symbolizes the union of two people.
- **Personification:** The flowers are personified as individuals capable of marriage.
**Contribution to Overall Theme:** This introduces the central metaphor of the poem, setting the tone of celebration and expectation for a beautiful union.

#### Lines 3-4
**Summary:** The poet wonders what will come next, expressing hope that a sweet and beautiful posterity will spring from this union.
**Literary Devices:**
- **Rhetorical Question:** "What next is look'd for?" engages the reader and emphasizes the poet's anticipation.
- **Imagery:** The idea of "spring from thee a sweet posterity" evokes images of new life and continuity.
**Contribution to Overall Theme:** These lines extend the hope for the future, suggesting that the union will result in a positive and lasting legacy.

### 3. Structure and Form
The poem consists of a single stanza of four lines, known as a quatrain. It follows a rhyme scheme of AABB, which creates a harmonious and rhythmic flow, reflective of the harmonious union it describes. The meter is iambic tetrameter, which gives the poem a steady and pleasing rhythm, enhancing the celebratory tone.

### 4. Imagery, Symbolism, and Figurative Language
- **Imagery:** The poem uses the imagery of flowers, specifically the lily and the rose, to evoke beauty, purity, and love.
- **Symbolism:** The lily often symbolizes purity and the rose symbolizes love and passion. Their union represents a perfect blend of these qualities.
- **Figurative Language:** The entire poem is an extended metaphor, comparing the marriage of two people to the union of two flowers, enriching the theme of natural beauty and harmony.

### 5. Tone and Mood
- **Tone:** The tone is celebratory and hopeful. The poet's admiration for the union and his optimistic outlook for the future are evident.
- **Mood:** The mood created for the reader is one of joy and anticipation. The imagery and rhythm contribute to a feeling of positivity and expectation for the future.

By intertwining the imagery of flowers with the concept of marriage, Robert Herrick crafts a poem that celebrates the beauty of union and the hope for a harmonious and prosperous future.

author: Archibald Lampman
title: The Martyrs.
poem:
Oh ye, who found in men's brief ways no sign
Of strength or help, so cast them forth, and threw
Your whole souls up to one ye deemed most true,
Nor failed nor doubted but held fast your line,
Seeing before you that divine face shine;
Shall we not mourn, when yours are now so few,
Those sterner days, when all men yearned to you,
White souls whose beauty made their world divine:
